meta_data.title: The Bow on Galatians
meta_data.subtitle: Galatians Summary Thanks to everyone who supports TMBH at  You're the reason we can all do this together!  Music by

transcription_data.text: Hey everybody, it's Matt. This is the 10 Minute Bible Hour Podcast and this is the final episode on Galatians season 5 and it's today and I'm sad to see it go because I've always loved this book but I love it different now than I used to love it before because I thought I knew what I was doing. So I picked this book so I was like, oh, I think this is an important one. I think I can help people understand God and the Bible better and then we started working on it and we got passed to the intro part and into the actual meat of the book, especially the middle few chapters and I found it to be quite humbling as an experience to turn on the microphone and talk with you about it every day for over a year and I feel like I learned a ton and I appreciate this book better now. That's why we do it, right? Because we think this is valuable materials. I mean, if you're like me, you think it's from God and that it's worth our time and attention. We want to make it a part of our daily rhythm and we did that and it worked on me and I'm the host. So I guess that's a giant win and I will miss Galatians because I've enjoyed being in this orbit geographically. I've enjoyed being in this orbit of the Bible. I've enjoyed hanging around with Paul, but we don't have to be done with Paul because the next season is on Philemon. And so yeah, I'm really excited for what's next. I'm just going to miss Galatians. This has been great today since it's our last conversation. I want to go big picture and I thought since it is our last day on Galatians, I brought my close personal friend, Jeffrey Foote in, Jeffrey, or can you make a grunt or something so that everybody knows. Hello. Oh, that was far better and more sophisticated than a grunt. Jeffrey, we're landing the plane. If after all of this experience, there was one thing you could draw a giant red circle around in our conversations and be like, hey, if you forgot all of the other things and you don't remember any of the fart jokes, remember this one thing. That's the biggest, most important thing from Galatians. What would it be? I think it's got to be 220, the theme of the whole book. I've been crucified with Christ, so it's no longer I who live, but Christ who lives in me and the life I now live, I live by faith in the one who loved me and gave himself for me. The idea that no one can be right with God by human effort. It's the work of Christ given to us. And then the Christian life is the life of Christ given to us, not the Christian trying harder through works, but by keeping in step with the spirit to bear his fruit. I mean, dude, that's just kind of Christianity. Yeah, it's amazing how they got it wrong so fast and how easy it is to get it wrong. I just think it's interesting when you put your words to it, which you're saying the same thing I am, but you're Jeffifying it. When you put your words to it, the way you summarize like, hey, if you just remember one thing, it's Christianity because that's what you just said. It is rich, thick, creamy, basic, essential, biblical gospel Christianity. So I guess then what you're saying is Galatians has the whole message, the whole Christian life, the front end, the middle, the back end. All of it is in Galatians. Yeah. And especially as opposed to we do the stuff to earn God's favor, what have you taken away in summary, the most basic thing is just the clown hammer point that Paul hits again and again and again. You cannot come away from Galatians imagining there are two ways to right standing with God and to the Christian life to life by the spirit. There is one way there are a billion wrong ways you could choose from. And even in the thing I did yesterday where we kind of did the quick overview of what the early church did with Galatians in response to heresies, they used Galatians to fend off a hundred different mutations of this, a hundred different false versions of the gospel, but all with the one singular way that is there. I mean, it's like the doctor strange holding up the one finger like there's only one way. We've run a billion simulations for how to have right standing with God, but there's only one. Right. But the interesting other side of that is how much more I've thought about why I want to do kingdom values, why I want fruit of the spirit in my life. And to some degree it's fear and it's always been fear. I mean, God is judge, he's real and he's true and he's the king of everything and all of his judgments are right. And I can't use my golden tongue to weasel out of anything with him. I can't negotiate my way out of trouble with him. He sees to the core of it and whatever his judgment and assessment is of what I did and why I did it is true. That is terrifying to someone like me because it means everything about me is laid bare and my best defense that can serve me so well when I'm wrongly accused or even sometimes when I'm rightly accused, it's not going to work on him. Yeah, I've been reflecting on why I want to obey God and have the fruit of the spirit manifest in my life more and some of that is born out of fear. But a lot more of that is born out of I want to look like what I am. I mean, I'm not even sure that's like a complete thought. Some sort of internal drive toward consistency. Yeah. Makes me feel like well, if if I am a Christian, I would like for there to be evidence of that. And I think the some of the history deep diver, at least the connection to acts was helpful for me in a similar way. Like remembering how he got beat up at all these cities and then the mob followed him to the next city. And then when he's done, he goes right back through them again and then the letter, which is a harsh letter, this was really, really hard for Paul to kind of get the center cut Christianity planted and to bloom in Galatia. And do I take it for granted? Yeah. And it was hard for him to internalize it in the first place. This guy's not untouched. He's living a complicated life. He happens to be right by the power of the Holy Spirit here, but it's hard for him. Well, and the story about Peter in the middle of Galatians, Peter knew the right answers. He preached a great sermon on Pentecost and he still needed to be reminded in front of everybody. Yeah. And I find that very encouraging even there, if the system that we had in place was that right standing with God is a result of me being a really good Christian boy who knows the right ideas and says the right phrases all the time. If we think that's how right standing with God happens, then Peter didn't have right standing with God around the time that he had that dinner table incident. But obviously Peter had right standing with God during that time. He was just wrong and his right standing with God was because of Christ, not because of Peter's perfect behavior at every dinner that he ever went to. Even when Peter messes up at the dinner party, the solution isn't do these 10 works and you'll get back to where you used to be. The solution is go back to faith, go back to how you got here. Yeah. Paul and Peter don't have that conversation, but Paul and the Galatians do. Same question I end up inevitably asking everybody who I talk deeply with and respect about this kind of thing. And I'm genuinely asking this isn't a podcast tee up question. Faith. Okay. So that's the thing that's the heart of it. And yet my experience with faith, actual human talking here is not linear growth. I had a spectacular couple of months of faith up until about a week ago as we're recording this. I don't know what the heck is wrong with me this week. I don't know. Nothing happened. Stuff just feels off. My track record tells me that in terms of faith and trust in God that it probably won't feel that way next week. I don't know. Maybe it'll be longer. I don't know. But you're right. Clearly the takeaway from the book is don't double down on works, double down on faith, but also sometimes I don't feel that intuitively at all. What do you do with that? I think that's what kind of the second half of the book is about in connecting with the Holy Spirit, that the faith that saves you has saved you, whether you feel it or not every day, but as you're going through the journey, you're not going to feel it every day. You're not going to always be on top of the mountain. You're going to have times of doubt. You're going to have times of numbness of being in the wilderness. I mean, we all do. We're going to have times of sinning when we know we shouldn't, but who you are isn't determined by what you do or how you feel. That's determined by what Jesus has done. And the Holy Spirit reminds us of what is true of our identity. So when we can connect with him or reconnect with him, it helps us through the drier times, which is probably more normal this side of heaven anyway. Like I think doubt is okay. The flesh is going to be weak. But if the spirit is there and if your spirit is willing to connect with the spirit, then you're on the right track. It's interesting that you said the word doubt. Sometimes I deal with doubt, maybe not in like the general sense. I've been there. I can say that. The word you use that resonated more with me was numbness. There are people sitting on this conversation for whom doubt is the thing. For me, the numbness thing is what does it? Them trying to do things that are useful, good, redemptive, keep my head above water. And then a week or two is gone and you just have this moment of what am I doing at all? What is any of this? I don't think this is what life by the spirit looks like, but I remember vividly the fruit of the spirit and stuff that feels like life by the spirit from like two weeks ago. So those little ebbs and flows seem to happen and maybe I've had enough of them that I don't quite panic as much anymore. Like, stuff's good, dude. Nothing's wrong. We talk almost every day. Things are great. But numbness. That's the word. And then I read these last few chapters of Galatians. Yeah, I kind of feel like something is off. Maybe that's why those verses are there. I think if we all just bad at a thousand on life in the spirit, we wouldn't need like half of our new Testament and we're in great company too. Like Paul is the guy who said, don't be anxious about anything. But like two pages before, he was saying, my friend is so sick and I'm having sorrow upon sorrow. I'm just so anxious about it. Yeah. I don't think linear is the way it's ever going to work. I think the ebb and flow is part of the journey. And I think life by the spirit is always going to be a little subjective, right? Not quantifiable because we're all different. I think that's a feature, not a bug. And I really think that's kind of why these verses are in here. Paul's not trying to make a theological point just to make a point. He's trying to help his friends. Yes. Yes. I hope that came through in the season. I think sometimes when I talk about Paul, he's such a retortician. It's easy to think in terms of he's trying to win an argument. And he is. And I mean, I think of him that way because that's how he holds himself out. But he cares about these people. Then he is trying to help his friends. And I don't know if I ever said that phrase or if it was uttered on this podcast in this season until right now, but you're right, he's trying to help his friends and you're picking up what I'm putting down. I mean, I hope it benefits other people too. But this is kind of a rhythm I need. Yeah. Some days it needs to be like this. A lot of days I just need to think about what it's doing. So I know what I'm actually dealing with and I need to just keep doing it again and again and again and take a chunk of time every day to think about him. It's like learning Spanish or Italian. If once a month I sit down and I hit language really hard, it doesn't work. But when I'm doing the best on language work, it's when, you know, it's just 10 minutes a day, just build it in, just drill some of these things that have been slipping a little bit on the Spanish and get that back together. And you're also right when it comes to numbness that Paul felt that crap. I mean, we, how many times have we talked about the second missionary journey? He leaves Galatia and goes to, you know, wherever he is at technically, frigia, Asia, and nothing works. Just doesn't happen prevented from preaching. And that one it turned out was actually ordained by God for some larger purpose with what would happen when he got on to, you know, Philippi and Thessalonica and stuff. So I don't know, I can't always see the awesome thing on the back end, but you know, when you do a season this long, it's interesting because there are pockets of great fervor and enthusiasm in the actual life that is unfolding during that season. And then there are pockets of just kind of, you know, like in master and commander when they're just sitting out there in the middle of the ocean and there's just no breeze, just doldrums like here we are, but we still got to tend to the ship and we're going to do it and we're going to have fun and we're going to do our best. So can I be bold and like speak for a big chunk of our audience? The history deep dive stuff that you always kind of apologize for doing, you don't have to. That's an amazing piece of all this that even somebody like me who has spent his life trying to master the Bible, it still blows my mind when some of these connections get made historically. I mean, I really liked doing that stuff. I was joking about it a couple episodes ago. I mean, will you heard it? You edit the thing. He wanted to make sure no one got the impression that God screwed up and did a bad job on the law, but rather the law did exactly what it was supposed to do. The problem wasn't with God. The problem was the misunderstanding on the part of people to imagine that the law served a purpose it does not serve could not serve was never meant to serve that the law was not designed to save, but that it was this teacher to teach us about God, man, and to point us toward Jesus. This is what we were talking about when I was telling you about how I feel lately. The life by the spirit thing, I mean, the book just isn't about how to become a Christian. It's about what happens now. What do you do? What are we doing here? Agreed. I was going to say this is implicit, but I think it's explicit. I think the final big theological theme is there is a true version of the gospel and there are true representatives of that. Listen to them. There are many false versions of the gospel and there are representatives of that. That isn't Christianity. That isn't the church. That isn't the gospel. It shows up a lot in the New Testament just to be on your guard against false teaching. Yeah. John in his epistles talks about just not even receiving false teachers. Don't give them hospitality. A lot of these things that at first glance might just seem like people being really nitpicky and wanting to fight about church things and be in pedantic. I understand that a knee jerk response to that can be, come on, we just need to get along. Let's not fight about God's stuff. Everybody's got their opinions or whatever. But the things that really matter, really matter if you look closely at what the Bible is saying, what Paul is saying in places like this, they matter because they strike at the heart of who God is, the heart of the whole point of the whole exercise and you basically rewire the whole thing and wreck the whole thing.
